channel.title: Golang Weekly
channel.description: A weekly newsletter about the Go programming language

item.title: ã€Some signal boosting for Goã€‘æœ‰äº›ä¿¡å·æå‡äº†
item.description:
ã€

#â€‹550 â€” April 16, 2025

UnsubÂ Â |Â Â WebÂ Version

ğŸ¥š We're taking a little break for Easter but didn't want to take the entire week off, so we have a slimline issue for you todayÂ :-) Back to full speed nextÂ Wednesday!
__
Peter Cooper, your editor

Go Weekly

Using Signals with Go â€” Signals are asynchronous messages sent to processes to notify them of events like interrupts, crashes or termination, or to trigger certain behaviors. Most languages let you catch signals and act upon them, such as for shutting down a program gracefully, and Go is noÂ exception.

Jon Calhoun

Complete Go for Professional Developers â€” Craft production-grade APIs with Go, the language trusted by tech giants! Connect to Postgres, implement auth, and write tests that matter. Taught by a Twitch ML engineer who solves real problems with GoÂ daily.

Frontend Masters sponsor

Fuzzing Go Binaries with LibAFL â€” Built upon the Rust-powered LibAFL fuzzing library, GoLibAFL brings â€˜state-of-the-art fuzzing techniquesâ€™ to Go developers. This post compares it to existing solutions, shows off some examples, and digs into how they tailored LibAFL for Go useÂ cases.

Ollrogge and Produit

sync.Pool is Not a Silver Bullet â€” sync.Pool can reduce allocations and GC pressure, but itâ€™s not a drop-in solution for every case. Jens looks at where pooling shines (predictable, short-lived objects) and when it canÂ backfire.

Jens Neuse

Hoard of the Rings: Extracting Data From a Cheap ActivityÂ Tracker â€” Tony picked up a cheap activity tracking (heartrate, steps, etc.) ring and figured out how to use TinyGo to read its outputs. A fun yet practical use forÂ TinyGo!

Tony Smith

ğŸ“„ Most People Overlook Goâ€™s Concurrency Secrets Aryan Mehrotra

ğŸ“„ Ten Commandments of Go John Arundel

ğŸ›  Code & Tools

Mockery v3: Create Mock Implementations of Interfaces â€” With the very bold claim of Mockery v3 being able to make â€œobsolete all other interface-based code generation frameworksâ€ in the Go world, the author has a good go at explaining why. If youâ€™d rather just see the facts and give it a go, the homepage is a good place toÂ start.

Landon Clipp

Bufstream: Robust Streaming for gRPC â€” Meet a cloud-first Kafka implementation custom-built for go gRPC streams. Plus, Bufstream isÂ Jepsenâ€‘tested.

Buf sponsor

Vite Backend Integration for Go â€” A way to integrate a Vite-based frontend with a Go-based backendÂ app.

Oliver Eilhard

  • Fyne 2.6 â€“ Cross platform GUI toolkit in Go. v2.6 introduces a new threading model that makes it a lotÂ faster.

  • AWS Lambda for Go 1.48 â€“ Samples & tools for Go devs building on AWSÂ Lambda.

  • pgxmock v4.7.0 â€“ Simulate pgx behavior in tests without a real DBÂ connection.

  • go-git v5.16.0 â€“ Extensible Git implementation written in pure Go.

  • Revive 1.9 â€“ Fast, configurable, extensible, flexible linter forÂ Go.

  • Mongo DB Driver 2.2 â€“ The official Go driver forÂ MongoDB.

ğŸ“¢Â  Elsewhere

A quick roundup of some other interesting updates or useful resources in the broader developerÂ landscape:

  • Miguel Young de la Sota explains what a 'target triple' is (those things that look like x86_64-unknown-linux and explain what architecture and OS a binary is targeting). Go gets a big mention due to its native support for cross compiling, but the author isn't particularly impressed with Go's approach toÂ targeting.

  • The MITRE-managed Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures (CVE) program is coming to an end this month due to a cut in DHS funding. However, The CVE Foundation has been rapidly created to carry on its essential cybersecurityÂ work.

  • ğŸ“˜ Dr. Axel Rauschmayer has released Exploring TypeScript: TS 5.8 Edition â€“ you can buy it, but also read it all online for free in HTML form.

  • ğŸ¤– Last week, Google unveiled Firebase Studio, an online agentic AI development environment somewhat akin to things you might have seen from v0, Cursor orÂ Lovable.

  • I rarely need to work with modern graphics or Web design techniques, but this look at creating a flowing WebGL gradient is a fascinating breakdown of using math and modern Web technologies to create a plasmaÂ effect.

ã€‘

__
Peter Cooper, your editor

  • MITREç®¡ç†çš„å¸¸è§æ¼æ´å’Œæš´éœ²ï¼ˆCVEï¼‰ç¨‹åº

item.title: ã€A Go-powered TUI email clientã€‘ä¸€ä¸ªä¾›ç”µçš„TUIç”µå­é‚®ä»¶å®¢æˆ·
item.description:
ã€

#â€‹552 â€” April 30, 2025

UnsubÂ Â |Â Â WebÂ Version

Go Weekly

The Draft Go 1.25 Release Notes â€” Weâ€™re still about four months away from the final Go 1.25 release (expected in August) but, as always, the release notes are being worked on in advance and already provide a useful glimpse into whatâ€™sÂ coming.

The Go Team

Using Differential Coverage for Debugging â€” Russ shows how to generate and diff coverage profiles from passing and failing tests to spotlight code unique to the failure. Itâ€™s not foolproof, but it can dramatically narrow your debugging searchÂ space.

Russ Cox

Is Your Go Application's Postgres Prepared for Your Next High Traffic Event? â€” Do you feel like your Postgres database is a black box? Watch Postgres expert Lukas Fittl walk through the latest pganalyze features to tune slow queries, catch regressions, and keep Postgres running at its best in this on-demandÂ video.

pganalyze sponsor

IN BRIEF:

  • ğŸ‘€ Ron Evans, of TinyGo and GoCV fame, has a new project: wasmVision. A new computer vision processing engine (built in Go, naturally) that can be customized and extended withÂ WebAssembly.

  • ğŸ¤– gpt-go is an attempt at building a simple GPT-style implementation in Go, trained on Jules Verne books. Don't expect GPT-4 levels of conversation here, but a coolÂ experiment.

This 150-Line Go Program is a Full-On Load Balancer â€” A code-heavy walkthrough of a round-robin load balancer built solely with the standard library. Itâ€™s not production-ready, but the author offers some recommendations for moving in thatÂ direction.

Rez Moss

Using the SIGHUP Signal for Configuration Reloads â€” The OS can send various â€˜signalsâ€™ to your Go apps and SIGHUP (â€œsignal hangupâ€) is one of the more interesting ones. Phuong explains its history, what itâ€™s often used for today, and how to catch and handleÂ it.

Phuong Le

ğŸ’¡ Jon Calhoun's Using Signals with Go covers the topic of signals moreÂ generally.

ğŸ“„ Go on the PlayStation 2: Part Two â€“ You seemed to enjoy Ricardoâ€™s first outing explaining how he got Go code running on the PS2. Now heâ€™s back withÂ more. Ricardo Gomes da Silva

ğŸ“º Comparing Error Handling in Zig and Go package main

ğŸ“„ How to Use Go's New tool Directive Alex Pliutau

ğŸ›  Code & Tools

Firebase Brings Its Genkit AI Framework to Go â€” Genkit is a framework for building AI-powered apps from Googleâ€™s Firebase team, though it can be used independently of Googleâ€™s APIs. Originally for Node.js, itâ€™s now in beta for GoÂ too.

Gill and Friese (Firebase)

Bufstream: Kafka and gRPC for the Modern Age â€” A drop-in Kafka implementation with up to 8x cost savings over self-managed. See how we doÂ it.

Buf sponsor

âœ‰ï¸Â ListMonk 5.0: Self-Hosted Newsletter & Mailing List Manager â€” If you donâ€™t want to pay to use a hosted newsletter system, how about a one binary Go solution? v5.0 introduces a visual drag-and-drop email builder and template editor. (Homepage.)

Kailash Nadh

  • GoReleaser v2.9 â€“ Originally for Go only, this Go-powered release generation tool has expanded into Rust, TypeScript, Zig and PythonÂ recently.

  • Anubis 1.17 â€“ Provides a proof-of-work challenge to 'weigh the soul' of incoming HTTP requests in an attempt to stop/slow down AIÂ crawlers.

  • Hugo 0.147.0 â€“ The popular Go-powered static site generator shows no sign of slowingÂ down.

  • Pion WebRTC v4.1.0 â€“ A pure Go implementation of the WebRTC API. Now with complete AV1Â support.

  • Micro 5.3 â€“ Go distributed system abstractions /Â platform.

  • Caire 1.5 â€“ Content aware image resizing library/tool.

  • Goyave 5.6 â€“ Enterprise REST APIÂ framework.

ğŸ“°Â Classifieds

Course: Complete Go for Professional Developers â€” Craft production-grade APIs with Go. Taught by a Twitch ML engineer who solves real problems with GoÂ daily.

ğŸ’ŒÂ  And a little bonus..

aerc: A Go-Powered Terminal-Based Email Client â€” Mix a little Pine with a little Vim and tmux and you get this Go-powered email client that supports HTML emails, PGP signing, IMAP/Maildir/SMTP and soÂ on.

Robin Jarry / Drew DeVault

ã€‘

item.title: ã€Don't Fear the Reaperã€‘ä¸è¦å®³æ€•æ”¶å‰²è€…
item.description:
ã€

#â€‹551 â€” April 23, 2025

UnsubÂ Â |Â Â WebÂ Version

Go Weekly

Cheating the Reaper in Go â€” How far can you push manual memory management in Go despite its garbage collector? Miguel peels back Goâ€™s GC internals to craft a blazing-fast arena allocator in pure Goâ€”with nothing more than unsafe wizardryâ€”and shows exactly when (and how) you can safely outmaneuver theÂ GCâ€™sÂ reaper.

Miguel Young de la Sota

A No Nonsense Guide to Go Project Layout â€” Say â€˜noâ€™ to overly complicated package structures, says the author, who shares a set of opinions for keeping things tight and focused with the goal of preventing â€˜over complicationâ€™ in smallerÂ projects.

Laurent Demailly

Bufstream: Robust Streaming for gRPC â€” Meet a cloud-first, drop-in Kafka implementation custom-built for go gRPC streams. Stateless, auto-scaling, schema-aware, and up to 8x cheaper than maintaining your own Kafka stack. Read the JepsenÂ report.

Buf sponsor

Optimizing Heap Allocations â€” When an (expected) innocuous code change had a 30% performance hit, it led to an enlightening forensic journey into stack vs heap allocation. Point yourself at this article to gain the value of understanding allocations and escape performanceÂ regressions.

Nick Tobey (DoltHub)

IN BRIEF:

  • Go's new json/v2 package is still in its proposal stages, but has been merged into Go behind an experimental flag. You can play with it now on the Go Playground here, however.

  • Hako is a new QuickJS-based JavaScript engine that compiles to WebAssembly and is designed to be embedded in other apps.. such as in this Go example!

  • JetBrains has released GoLand 2025.1, the latest version of its popular commercial Go IDE. Its AI features get a major upgrade, there's support for golangci-lint, full support for Go 1.24, and other improvements allÂ round.

  • The Socket security platform now has first-class support for Go.

Hunting Zombie Processes in Go and Docker â€” When spawning processes that in turn spawn other processes, you can run into issues where some unwanted processes stick around as zombies. This post looks at one such situation, how containers made it even messier, and how the zombies ultimately got takenÂ out.

Savas Vedova (Stormkit)

Preventing Accidental Struct Copies â€” Go lets you copy structs by value, which can cause subtle bugsâ€”especially with locks like sync.WaitGroup or Mutex. This post digs into how a noCopy trick and go vetâ€™s copylocks checker can catch theseÂ issues.

Redowan Delowar

ğŸ“„ 15 Reasons I Love Go â€“ Save this for the next time you get frustrated. Christoph Berger

ğŸ“„ Don't Overload Your Brain: Write Simple Go Jakub Jarosz

ğŸ“º How to Use Go's New tool Directive package main

ğŸ›  Code & Tools

GoMud: A MUD (Multi-User Dungeon) Server â€” An in-development open source dungeon game world and library that handles the main concepts associated with MUDs, like maps, inventory and equipment, day/night cycles, etc, and allows players to connect over Telnet orÂ HTTP.

Volte6 et al.

ğŸ–¼ï¸Â ImageProxy 0.12: A Caching Proxy Server and Transformer for ImageÂ Files â€” A long-standing project that provides a way to efficiently host image files while also allowing for basic transformations such as resizing, cropping and rotation. v0.12 is the first release in a few years and updates dependencies and adds a module forÂ Caddy.

Will Norris

Go Event-Driven: Build Backend Systems That Actually Scale â€” Join 1000+ developers coding real projects in your IDE. No videos, just hands-on practice. Spring cohort opensÂ soon.

Three Dots Labs sponsor

ğŸ¤–Â MCP Go: A Go Implementation of the Model Context Protocol â€” The Model Context Protocol (MCP) is a rapidly growing way to provide a way for LLMs and AI agent based devtools with access to external services. Why let Pythonistas have all the fun when you could be developing your own MCP servers withÂ Go?

Anthropic

Doltgres Beta Launch: A Version Controlled SQL Database â€” As well as dropping lots of great Go articles on their blog, the folks at DoltHub also develop database software ;-) Doltgres is a Postgres-flavored variant of their SQL database that offers Git-style merging and forking, and itâ€™s all built inÂ Go.

Zach Musgrave (DoltHub)

  • Glamour 0.10 â€“ Stylesheet-based Markdown rendering for CLI apps, now with much easier to read tables and prettier GitHubÂ links.

  • FastHTTP 1.61 â€“ Performance-oriented alternative to net/http for specific high-volumeÂ scenarios.

  • urfave/cli 3.2.0 â€“ Popular way to declaratively build Go-powered command lineÂ tools.

  • go-elasticsearch 9.0 â€“ Official Elasticsearch clientÂ library.

  • Caddy 2.10 â€“ Powerful Go-powered HTTP server with automaticÂ HTTPS. Now with Encrypted ClientHello (ECH)Â support.

  • Chroma 2.17 â€“ General purpose syntax highlighter in pureÂ Go.

  • gRPC-Go 1.72 â€“ Go implementation of gRPC for HTTP/2 basedÂ RPC.

  • quic-go 0.51 â€“ Pure Go QUICÂ implementation.

ğŸ“¢Â  Elsewhere

A quick roundup of some other interesting updates or useful resources in the broader developerÂ landscape:

  • The maximum lifetime of TLS certificates is set to be reduced to 47 days in a gradual process between early 2026 and 2029.

  • KDE's Kate text editor is less widely used than VS Code or Vim, say, but it's more powerful than you might think with support for plugins, debugging, and LSPs â€“ here's one developer's KateÂ workflow.

  • The Microsoft Edge team is proposing enhancing the console.context() method to help make it more useful to developers with visual tweaks and a filteringÂ mechanism.

  • ğŸ“Š We're big fans of the Val Town JavaScript platform and Orestis Papadopoulos shows how he managed to quickly put together a basic analytics feature for his site with it.

  • Ubuntu 25.04 'Plucky Puffin' has been released. It's a non-LTS release however, so only gets support for nineÂ months.

  • TIL you can interact with GitHub's GraphQL API with the GitHub CLI tool.

ã€‘

â€” The Model Context Protocol (MCP) is a rapidly growing way to provide a way for LLMs and AI agent based devtools with access to external services.å½“æ‚¨å¯ä»¥ä½¿ç”¨GOå¼€å‘è‡ªå·±çš„MCPæœåŠ¡å™¨æ—¶ï¼Œä¸ºä»€ä¹ˆè®©æ¯•è¾¾æ–¯å¡”æ–¯éƒ½èƒ½è·å¾—æ‰€æœ‰ä¹è¶£ï¼Ÿ

äººç±»

- ä»¥åŠåœ¨ data datapase at database s ddataubs s ot database s ot oftware ;-) Doltgresæ˜¯å…¶SQLæ•°æ®åº“çš„Postgreså‘³é“å˜ä½“ï¼Œå¯æä¾›GITé£æ ¼çš„åˆå¹¶å’Œåˆ†å‰ï¼Œå¹¶ä¸”å…¨éƒ¨å†…ç½®ã€‚

Zach Musgraveï¼ˆDolthubï¼‰

item.title: ã€Does Go need bare metal support?ã€‘å»éœ€è¦è£¸æœºæ”¯æ’‘å—ï¼Ÿ
item.description:
ã€

#â€‹553 â€” May 7, 2025

UnsubÂ Â |Â Â WebÂ Version

Go Weekly

Practical Patterns for Graceful Shutdowns â€” Shutting down gracefully can mean the difference between a good user experience with consistent data and angry users (or even just yourself!) with corrupted data. Follow and adapt this five-step approach, and shutting down wonâ€™t open you up toÂ issues.

Phuong Le (VictoriaMetrics)

Proposal: Add Bare Metal Support to Go? â€” Andrea proposes a new 'none' target for the Go compiler to enable freestanding execution without direct OS support. This isnâ€™t exactly new ground â€“ itâ€™s been proposed before â€“ but Go contributor Filippo Valsorda thinks itâ€™s worth serious consideration again due to the opportunities it would open up in micro VMs, firmware, andÂ elsewhere. It's also been discussed internally atÂ Google.

Andrea Barisani et al.

Cut Go Code Review Time and Bugs in Half â€” Code reviews are time-consuming. CodeRabbit is your AI co-pilotâ€”instantly generating review comments, one-click fixes, and custom AST-grep rules. It can even plan refactors and merge via chat. Trusted on 10M+ PRs across 1M repos and 70K+ OSSÂ projects.

CodeRabbit sponsor

wget to Wipeout: Malicious Go Modules Fetch DestructiveÂ Payload â€” A cautionary tale of a recent, stealthy supply-chain attack, by way of some malicious Go modules, which saw a single line of code wipe an entire disk clean. As ever, take care over yourÂ dependencies.

Kush Pandya (Socket)

Organize Your Go Middleware Without Dependencies â€” Go 1.22 introduced some enhancements to HTTP routing, so now it could make a lot of sense to remove dependencies around routing and handle things like middleware yourself. It doesn't take much code,Â either.

Alex Edwards

Building a More Accessible GitHub CLI â€” GitHubâ€™s CLI tool is powered by Go and the GitHub team shares the challenges faced for making it more accessible (with before-and-after videos) to screen readers and those with special visual requirements in particular. Popular Go library creators Charm make an appearance to lend a handÂ too.

Ryan Hecht and Andrew Feller (GitHub)

ğŸ“¢ Go 1.24.3 and 1.23.9 have been released. v1.24.3 includes a security fix for a path traversalÂ bug.

ğŸ“„ Bloom Filters Explained, and Implemented, in Go â€“ A perennially useful probabilistic dataÂ structure. Eli Bendersky

ğŸ“„ How to Find and Fix Vulnerable Dependencies with govulncheck â€“ Seemed worth a new mention! Go Docs
